CARDINAL- There is no power of attorney attesting that PERSON and GPE PERSON had given authority to the GPE representative . Therefore , the first - instance court should have rendered a decision pursuant to LAW in respect of these CARDINAL plaintiffs .

CARDINAL- According to the letter of ORG dated DATE , the land in dispute is located within the military security zone . As mentioned in this letter , there is no control of the use of the property as rural land ( arazi ) . The owner of the land can use it subject to the authorisation of ORG . Since the plot in question is rural land [ as opposed to urban land ( arsa ) ] , there is no de facto expropriation and , therefore , the plaintiffs can not request compensation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the authorities carried out an inspection of the applicants’ land ( plot no . CARDINAL ) . The inspection report , prepared by a real estate expert , stated that the LOC had been visited in the company of the village mayor and that it had been observed that the plot in question had stayed outside the fence . Furthermore , the land was not occupied and there was no obstacle to cultivation . Yet it had been noted that , according to some witnesses , the land was only used to grow grass ( for animals ) and not cultivated .
CARDINAL . The relevant page of the log book kept at the GPE land registry office indicates that PERSON , the applicants’ ancestor , had been the owner of the land in dispute .
CARDINAL . A description of the relevant domestic law and practice can be found in GPE v. GPE ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL , DATE .

CARDINAL . It appears from the established practice of ORG that when land is located within a restricted military zone the owners of the land in question can not claim compensation for de facto expropriation unless the administration permanently denies access to that land with the intention of owning it ( see , in particular , decision no . CARDINAL on file no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL of ORG of ORG ) . Furthermore , such restriction is not considered de facto expropriation . Accordingly , the litigants can not claim compensation for the value of their land . However , they may obtain compensation for temporary denial of access to land or damage resulting from restrictions imposed on the use of their land .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW provides as follows :
“ All acts or decisions of the administration are subject to judicial review .
The administration shall be liable to indemnify any damage caused by its own acts and measures . ”
